metadata.dc:author: Lago Núñez, Mar
González Lahoz, Juan
Valencia Ortega, M Eulalia
Holguín Fernández, Africa
Alvarez Ferrero, Amparo
Moreno Celda, Victoria
metadata.dc:description: BACKGROUND AND OBJECTIVE To analyse the characteristics and HIV-1 subtype in a group of HIV+ hospitalised immigrants in our Infectious Diseases Unit. PATIENTS AND METHOD Clinical reports of 78 immigrants HIV+ were reviewed. HIV-1 subtyping was carried out examining the protease and transcriptase genes by phylogenetic analysis. Statistical study was done by SPSS 11.0 program. RESULTS 57% of patients come from sub-Saharian Africa. Mainly they had been infected by heterosexual contact. HIV was diagnosed at the hospitalisation time in 35 cases. Only 28% were receiving highly active antiretroviral therapy and 48,7% had CD4+ cells less than 200/microl. The more frequent diagnosed diseases were: tuberculosis (20.5%), candidiasis (24.4%), bacterial pneumonia (19.2%) and malaria (21.8%). HIV-1 subtype B was isolated in 26 patients, none Africans. Twenty nine individuals (52.8%) were infected with HIV-1 non-B subtypes. Relationship between HIV-1 subtype, immunodepression, diagnosed diseases and origin countries was not found apart from malaria. CONCLUSIONS Most HIV-1 infected immigrants are from Africa, being predominantly infected with HIV-1 non-B subtypes. No relationship between HIV subtype and diagnosed diseases was found.
metadata.dc:title: Infección por el virus de la inmunodeficiencia humana tipo 1 e inmigración: manifestaciones clínicas, subtipos y evolución de 78 pacientes ingresados durante los últimos 5 años.
[Immigration and HIV-1 infection: clinical manifestations, subtypes and evolution of 78 patients attended during the last 5 years].
